This post explains what it means for $\epsilon=\text{min}(x-a,b-x)$. 

![](smol-epsilon.webp)

# `Explanation`

Consider the real number line $\mathbb{R}$ and some value x which lies between (a,b). When $\epsilon=\text{min}(x-a,b-x)$ then $\epsilon$ is equal to $2\times$ smaller distance to either a or b. For example, in the picture below x is closer to a, so x-a is smaller than b-x. Therefore $\epsilon=2(x-a)$. 

![](epsilon.png)

If it helps to apply values consider $a=1$, $b=4$, and $x=2$. Then 

$\epsilon=\text{min}(x-a,b-x)=\text{min}(2-1,4-2)=\text{min}(1,2)=2(1)=2$
